awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Eco-geomorphic response of coastal carbon to accelerated sea level rise
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is to determine how the carbon sequestered in coastal marshes will respond to sea level rise. The research will develop a computer model of tidal marsh carbon cycling that will be tested with data collected from across the Chesapeake Bay region. This work will illuminate how one of the world's largest carbon sinks will respond to climate change, and help land managers evaluate the degree to which marsh migration into drowning uplands will offset losses due to coastal erosion.

Marshes and other shallow-water coastal environments are responsible for about half of all marine carbon sequestration, but little is known about how this carbon will respond to sea level rise and growing coastal infrastructure such as levees. Analysis of historical maps and marsh soils will be used to determine how fast carbon-rich marsh soils are developing on drowning land, and whether Chesapeake marshes have grown or contracted in response to the last century of sea level rise. Computer modeling will then be used to predict how marsh size and soil carbon content will respond to future sea level rise. The project will engage local community college and American Indian students, and provide land managers and policy makers with information about the fate and value of a prominent coastal ecosystem.

inst.inst_name: College of William & Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science

por.por_cntn:
We discovered 100,000 acres of marsh that formed as result of sea level rise in the Chesapeake Bay region in the last 150 years. This new marshland formed at slightly higher, more inland locations, typically replacing coastal forests and farmland. Our research linked rates of ecosystem migration to rates of sea level rise, suggesting that ghost forests and abandoned farmland are the most striking indicators of climate change on the Atlantic Coast. Despite relative sea level rise rates that are among the highest in the world, marsh creation exceeded marsh loss across the mid-Atlantic U.S. Nevertheless, marsh migration led to important changes in carbon stocks, and likely other ecosystem functions. For example, sea level rise leads to a shift from coastal carbon stocks dominated by forest biomass to stocks dominated by wetland soils. Together, the research implies that marsh migration may be a primary mechanism for land managers to preserve expansive marshland under rapid sea level rise. Finally, the project facilitated river trips with members of the Nause Waiwash, Upper Mattaponi, and Pamunkey Indian tribes, and directly supported training and professional development of students from Thomas Nelson Community College, Virginia Institute of Marine Science, and William & Mary. These interactions led to new observations, generated fresh ideas, and greatly enhanced the work.
